commit_message:
Resource providers: custom resource classes

Adds ability for cloud admins to create custom dynamic resource classes.

Change-Id: I14bb3500eba74a69c665c7ddb96d5d99bef66d85
Blueprint: custom-resource-classes
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/96/312696/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================= Resource Providers - Dynamic Resource Classes ============================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/resource-providers-dynamic-resource-classes We propose to provide the ability for an administrator to create a set of special resource classes that indicate atomic resources that can be provided by a generic resource pool. Problem description =================== Some hardware resources should be represented as a singular unit of consumable resource. These singular units of consumable resources may vary from one cloud offering to another, and attempting to create a standardized resource class identifier for these types of resources that can be used across different OpenStack clouds is not possible. We require a method for cloud administrators to create new resource classes that represent atomically allocatable units of some resource. Use Cases --------- As a cloud deployer providing specialized hardware or baremetal resources to my users, I wish to utilize the new generic resource pools functionality to allow the Nova scheduler to understand how these specialized resources are laid out in my cloud deployment. Representing baremetal resources ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ When a cloud deployment chooses to offer a baremetal-as-a-service offering through Ironic, they currently create one Nova flavor for every distinct configuration of server hardware that they offer to customers. These flavors represent an atomically allocated unit of consumable hardware. In other words, a single Ironic baremetal node can serve one and only one Nova instance at a time. There is currently a single `nova-compute` daemon that "manages" all Ironic baremetal nodes in a deployment. It exposes all baremetal nodes' details to the Nova scheduler as though they were discrete hypervisors, where the hypervisor name is the baremetal node UUID. The Nova scheduler determines the unique combination of (host, node) on which to place a requested instance workload, and the singular `nova-compute` daemon passes the request down to the baremetal service to place the given instance on the specific node. It is not possible to run more than one such process per Nova region, because every `nova-compute` process will report on all available baremetal nodes in the baremetal service it connects to. This single `nova-compute` process is a bottleneck for workload scheduling and placement; for very large deployments, it is not possible to scale out this process. It is therefore also a single point of failure. With the new `generic-resource-pools` functionality being added to the Nova scheduler in Newton, there is potential to solve both the performance issues associated with a single `nova-compute` daemon managing all Ironic instances as well as the poor user experience resulting in few placement options to the baremetal user. If there was a way to create resource class identifiers for configurations of baremetal hardware, we could have an external process (or the ironic Nova virt driver) create and manage the inventory for a series of generic resource pools containing amounts of each class of baremetal configuration. It's easiest to see how this works by walking through an example. Let's assume that we have 1000 baremetal machines in our datacenter that we wish to offer to users via Ironic. 750 of these machines correspond to this configuration: * dual-socket 8-core Intel CPU with hyperthreading * 128GB RAM * 800GB HDD * 2x1GB NICs We will call this configuration `IRON_BASE`. 250 of the machines correspond to a configuration more performance-conscious setup: * dual-socket 12-core Intel CPU with hyperthreading * 256GB RAM * 1.2TB SSD * 2x1GB NICs * 2x10GB NICs (SR-IOV enabled) We will call this configuration `IRON_NFV`. The cloud operator wants to use 10 `nova-compute` daemons for managing Ironic instances, so they start 10 `nova-compute` daemons, possibly in containers:: # Assume 10 containers with IP addresses 10.0.3.11 through 10.0.3.21 # have been created and contain the nova-compute packages... for x in `seq 11 21`; do ssh user@10.0.3.$x 'service nova-compute start' done Starting the `nova-compute` service daemon in each container will create a compute node record in the Nova database for that host/IP address. We will need an aggregate to associate a generic resource pool with, so the cloud operator creates one for each hardware configuration:: BASE_AGG_UUID=`openstack aggregate create iron_base_aggregate` NFV_ADD_UUID=`openstack aggregate create iron_nfv_aggregate` The cloud operator would like 7 of the `nova-compute` daemons to manage the `IRON_BASE` resources and 3 to manage the `IRON_NFV` resources, and therefore they link the first seven of the compute nodes with the first aggregate and the last three with the second aggregate:: for x in `seq 11 18`; do openstack aggregate add host $BASE_AGG_UUID '10.0.3.$x' done for x in `seq 19 21`; do openstack aggregate add host $NFV_ADD_UUID '10.0.3.$x' done Now the cloud operator creates two generic resource pools, one for each hardware configuration:: BASE_IRON_RP_UUID=`openstack resource-pool create iron_base_pool \ --aggregate-uuid=$BASE_AGG_UUID` NFV_IRON_RP_UUID=`openstack resource-pool create iron_nfv_pool \ --aggregate-uuid=$NFV_AGG_UUID` At this point, the cloud operator needs to set the inventory of each of the resource pools. **However, there is no resource class that represents the `IRON_BASE` or `IRON_NFV` hardware configurations**. So, we need to create new resource classes for these hardware configurations:: openstack resource-class create IRON_BASE openstack resource-class create IRON_NFV .. note:: The `openstack resource-class create` CLI call above does not currently exist and would be added in the scope of this blueprint. Now the cloud operator can set the inventory of the two resource pools create earlier:: openstack resource-pool update inventory $BASE_IRON_RP_UUID \ --resource-class=IRON_BASE --total=750 --reserved=0 \ --max-unit=1 --min-unit=1 --allocation-ratio=1.0 openstack resource-pool update inventory $NFV_IRON_RP_UUID \ --resource-class=IRON_NFV --total=250 --reserved=0 \ --max-unit=1 --min-unit=1 --allocation-ratio=1.0 The cloud admin would need to indicate that the Nova flavors offered for baremetal instances indicated that one `IRON_BASE` or `IRON_NFV` resource was consumed. Let's say that the Nova flavors are called "metal.gold" and "metal.platinum". The "metal.gold" flavor would consume one `IRON_BASE` resource and the "nova.platinum" flavor would consume one `IRON_NFV` resource:: openstack flavor set metal.gold \ --property resources:IRON_BASE:1 openstack flavor set metal.platinum \ --property resources:IRON_NFV:1 .. note:: The "resources:IRON_BASE:1" custom extra-spec property above isn't what I would ideally like to use to represent quantitative resources for an instance type. However, this extra specs system is what we currently have and it's out of scope for this spec to fix that. At this point, Nova has the information it needs to place requested workloads to any of the 10 `nova-compute` daemons. Requests for the higher-end NFV-specific "metal.platinum" Nova flavor will be placed on the `nova-compute` daemons in the `iron_nfv_aggregate` and will consume resources out of the `iron_nfv_pool` resource pool. Requests for the "metal.gold" flavor will be placed on the `nova-compute` daemons in the `iron_base_aggregate` and will consume resources out of the `iron_base_pool`. .. note:: The operator could also choose to use a single aggregate and assign that aggregate to all compute nodes and have a single generic resource pool containing multiple inventory records, one for the IRON_BASE and one for the IRON_NFV resource class. FPGA slot context resources ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ A field-programmable gate array (FPGA) is a piece of specialized hardware that is typically used to accelerate particular pieces of critical code. Some or all of the FPGA can be programmed with embedded systems code and then a fixed number of execution contexts allow one or more guests to utilize this hardware-accelerated program. When describing a consumable resource that an FPGA provides, we generally refer to these fixed number of contexts that provide access to a particular embedded program in the FPGA. So, the resource class in this sense refers to a particular piece of embedded systems code that is housed in the FPGA that is on a compute node. The difference between this use case and the use case that uses generic resource pools is that there is no resource pool concept here. The FPGA program contexts are resources that are local to a particular compute node and may only be consumed by instances on that compute node. By contrast, resources provided by a resource pool may be consumed by instances on many compute nodes. Therefore, we will need some method to allow the operator to tell Nova that a compute node has one or more FPGA program contexts available for instances to consume. Dynamic resource classes to the rescue. Let's say that an NFV cloud deployment has 20 baremetal machines that each have an Altera FPGA. These FPGAs have been loaded with one of two different programs to accelerate critical portions of the Telco's network switching infrastructure: * Some part of OpenVSwitch, let's call this `PROG_OVS` * Some cryptography functionality, let's call this `PROG_CRYPTO` 8 of the compute nodes' FPGAs have the `PROG_OVS` program loaded. 12 of the compute nodes have the `PROG_CRYPTO` program loaded in their FPGA. .. note:: We make no statement about how the FPGAs are loaded with synthesized RTL netlists. This is out of scope for this spec and possibly out of scope for Nova itself. Each FPGA program allows 4 execution contexts. First, the cloud operator will need to create new resource classes for the `PROG_OVS` and `PROG_CRYPTO` FPGA program execution contexts:: openstack resource-class create PROG_OVS openstack resource-class create PROG_CRYPTO .. note:: The `openstack resource-class create` CLI call above does not currently exist and would be added in the scope of this blueprint. The cloud operator will need some interface to tell Nova that certain compute nodes have the `PROG_OVS` program and some have the `PROG_CRYPTO` program:: # Assume the compute nodes are named cn1 through cn20 # and that the first eight compute nodes have the PROG_OVS program for x in `seq 1 8`; do openstack compute-node update inventory cn$x \ --resource-class=PROG_OVS \ --total=4 --reserved=0 --min-unit=1 --max-unit=1 done # and the last twleve compute nodes have the PROG_CRYPTO program for x in `seq 9 20`; do openstack compute-node update inventory cn$x \ --resource-class=PROG_CRYPTO \ --total=4 --reserved=0 --min-unit=1 --max-unit=1 done .. note:: The `openstack compute-node update inventory` CLI call above does not currently exist and would be added in the scope of this blueprint. The NFV cloud admin wants their virtual network function manager (VNFM) to be able to launch workloads in Nova where the guest will have access to an execution context for a particular known FPGA program. Some of the virtual machine instances housing virtual evolved packet core (vEPC) virtual network functions (VNFs) will need access to the accelerated OVS program. Other VNFs that compose the virtual IP multimedia subsystem (vIMS) will need access to the accelerated cryptography program for use in transcoding. The NFV cloud admin would create a Nova flavor that had in its set of requested resources a request for either a `PROG_OVS` or `PROG_CRYPTO` FPGA program execution context:: # A flavor for the crypto-centric VNFs openstack flavor create nfv.ovs auto 4096 4 0 openstack flavor set nfv.ovs \ --property resources:PROG_OVS:1 # And a similar flavor for the crypto-centric VNFs openstack flavor create nfv.ovs auto 4096 4 0 openstack flavor set nfv.ovs \ --property resources:PROG_OVS:1 .. note:: The "resources:PROG_OVS:1" custom extra-spec property above isn't what I would ideally like to use to represent quantitative resources for an instance type. However, this extra specs system is what we currently have and it's out of scope for this spec to fix that. At this point, Nova has all the information it needs in order to places instances launched with the "nfv.ovs" flavor onto compute nodes with available FPGA execution contexts for the OVS-specific FPGA program. Likewise, Nova can place instances launched with the "nfv.crypto" flavor to the compute nodes with available contexts for the crypto-specific FPGA program. Proposed change =============== We propose the addition of a few things: * Changes to the `nova.objects.fields.ResourceClass` Enum to handle dynamic resource classes above a certain integer index range * REST API for adding new resource classes This REST API would extend the new placement API added in the `generic-resource-pools` blueprint with the ability to add custom resource classes * REST API for setting dynamic resource class inventory records for a compute node * Changes to the scheduler to look for "resource:$RESOURCE_CLASS:$AMOUNT" extra specs codes for requested amounts of a dynamic resource class in a flavor and consider these requested resource amounts in the same way as any other resource class Alternatives ------------ None. Data model impact ----------------- The `nova.objects.fields.ResourceClass` is an Enum field that lists the standard known resource classes like VCPU, RAM_MB, DISK_GB, etc. We will need to make some modifications to this class and the object models that have a `ResourceClass` field (`Allocation` and `Inventory` object models). We will create a new `ResourceClass` **object model** that is wire-compatible with the `ResourceClass` Enum field. This new `ResourceClass` object model would look up its integer index values in a new API database `resource_classes` table instead of the currently hard-coded Enum index values. We would want to create some constants on this `ResourceClass` object model for the existing integer and string constants from the Enum `ResourceClass` for the "standardized" resource classes so that when clouds refer to one of those resource classes, they always refer to the same string/integer combination. This new `ResourceClass` object model might look something like this:: # /nova/objects/resource_class.py class ResourceClass(ovo.ObjectBase): # These come from the original ResourceClass Enum field VCPU = 'VCPU' MEMORY_MB = 'MEMORY_MB' DISK_GB = 'DISK_GB' PCI_DEVICE = 'PCI_DEVICE' SRIOV_NET_VF = 'SRIOV_NET_VF' NUMA_SOCKET = 'NUMA_SOCKET' NUMA_CORE = 'NUMA_CORE' NUMA_THREAD = 'NUMA_THREAD' NUMA_MEMORY_MB = 'NUMA_MEMORY_MB' IPV4_ADDRESS = 'IPV4_ADDRESS' # These come from the original ResourceClass Enum field. The order # below is important STANDARD_RES_CLASSES = ( VCPU, RAM_MB, DISK_GB, PCI_DEVICE, SRIOV_NET_VF, NUMA_SOCKET, NUMA_CORE, NUMA_THREAD, NUMA_MEMORY_MB, IPV4_ADDRESS, ) MIN_CUSTOM_RESOURCE_CLASS_INDEX = 1000 ... @classmethod def index(cls, name): if name in cls.STANDARD_RES_CLASSES: return cls.STANDARD_RES_CLASSES.index(name) return cls._from_db( model_query(api_models.ResourceClass).filter(name=name) ) @classmethod def from_index(cls, index): if index < cls.MIN_CUSTOM_RESOURCE_CLASS_INDEX: return cls.STANDARD_RES_CLASSES[index] return cls._from_db( model_query(api_models.ResourceClass).filter(id=index) ) REST API impact --------------- TODO Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: jaypipes Other contributors: cdent Work Items ---------- TODO Dependencies ============ * `generic-resource-pools` blueprint implemented Testing ======= TODO Documentation Impact ==================== We will need documentation for the operator that walks through various use case examples. References ========== None. History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Newton - Introduced

commit_message:
Add network address builtins to datalog

Basic coverage for IP comparisons, Network comparisons,
and IP inclusion in Networks.

Closes-bug: 1638743
Change-Id: If9c3eb2bea0c4fb1d50dfd38371021a9670f56ba

'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-11-21 09:46:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector/commit/4de684295d992f7f383596088385a5e7d9a985ec', 'message': 'Stop disabling the Neutron tempest plugin

The root cause of the bug #1621791 turns out to be a Neutron devstack
plugin patch[1] that removes a route to the tenant router.  Ironic
however relyies on that route to talk to IPA[2].  The devstack code to
set that route now exists in the Ironic plugin[2].  Disabling the
Neutron tempest plugin is therefore not necessary anymore.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/397987
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/399632

Closes-bug: #1621791
Change-Id: Icaca019880054e1d89b81736c2815a222e8abc45

The root cause for the Inspector grenade failures was an eventlet
monkey patch[1]. The issue now being solved, disabling the Neutron
tempest plugin is no longer necessary.

Closes-bug: #1621791
Change-Id: Icaca019880054e1d89b81736c2815a222e8abc45
'}]
commit_message:
Stop disabling the Neutron tempest plugin

The root cause for the Inspector grenade failures was an eventlet
monkey patch[1]. The issue now being solved, disabling the Neutron
tempest plugin is no longer necessary.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/399469/

Closes-bug: #1621791
Change-Id: Icaca019880054e1d89b81736c2815a222e8abc45
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector refs/changes/78/399478/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: if os.path.exists('/tmp/ironic-inspector-grenade'): # FIXME(dtantsur): pretend like Neutron does not exist due to # random failures, see https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1621791. cfg.CONF.set_override('neutron', False, 'service_available')

commit_message:
drop pytimeparse requirement

use pandas timedelta as it offers comparable single item parsing
and better batch parsing

Change-Id: Ifd79385a4363ae4a9da5e9e94513ac98c7cdb1cb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi refs/changes/89/395089/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: from oslo_utils import strutils from oslo_utils import timeutils from pytimeparse import timeparse return float(timeparse.timeparse(six.text_type(window)))

commit_message:
Clean imports in code

This patch set modifies lines which are importing objects
instead of modules. As per openstack import guide lines, user should
import modules in a file not objects.

http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#imports

Change-Id: If2a817aad1dd9939f8baa58a7fcde39438fe680c

commit_message:
Uses Ceph/Hammer repos for Liberty and Mitaka only

The use of Ceph/Hammer is not for all stable branches but only for
the Liberty and Mitaka stable releases; Newton will use Ceph/Jewel
instead. This change moves the Ceph repo admonitions within the
relevant stable branch.

Also suggests upgrade of 'cephstorage' nodes before 'compute' nodes
so that Ceph cluster is upgraded to the newest release before the
OpenStack upgrade is started.

Change-Id: Ia12e4f7d6fa7b8ecff7dcec6b5cd85804a049070

The method assertEquals has been deprecated since python 2.7.
http://docs.python.org/2/library/unittest.html#deprecated-aliases

Also in Python 3, a deprecated warning is raised when using assertEquals

Change-Id: Ie6b881f594c0b3e7015e70a12d7ac720fa765736
'}]
commit_message:
Replace assertEquals with assertEqual

The method assertEquals has been deprecated since python 2.7.
http://docs.python.org/2/library/unittest.html#deprecated-aliases

Also in Python 3, a deprecated warning is raised when using assertEquals
therefore we should use assertEqual instead.

This is part of blueprint assertequal

Change-Id: Ie6b881f594c0b3e7015e70a12d7ac720fa765736

commit_message:
Make powering off nodes after cleaning optional

This patch adds the option deploy.power_off_after_cleaning, default
true, which can be set to false to prevent ironic powering nodes off
after cleaning is completed. This can be useful for deployers who
want quicker deployments, as ironic will use the pre-booted agent
for deployment rather than having to wait a full POST cycle before
starting deployment.

Change-Id: I31029da6c768e29da0367efd4e2d3042d0f8b8d6
Related-bug: 1531217
Co-Authored-By: Josh Gachnang <josh@servercobra.com>

commit_message:
Fix the required package variable name

The variable 'gnocchi_required_pip_packages' is incorrectly named,
resulting in the potential for the packages in the list not being
built in the repo build and causing other issues with anything
that uses that pattern to find the package list.

This patch corrects the variable name to match the pattern across
all other roles.

Change-Id: Ie636dfeb4497c8d3703977bd55d53d1efba7d539

commit_message:
release 0.3.0 of django-openstack-auth-kerberos

this will be the final release of the library, it includes a
proper deprecation warning.

commit_message:
Fix test_unwatch_log() to cleanup after itself

Use get_temp_file_patch() so a unique directory is used
for test files, and so that anything created will get
cleaned-up on completion.

Change-Id: Ie3473906f87fdf270f1a67c16ed511b38b597755

commit_message:
Remove timeutils.clear_time_override in neutron

The clear_time_override function in timeutils was written as a
helper function to mock utcnow for unittests before 'mock' was
generally used. Now that we have mock and fixture, we no longer
need to use it.

Change-Id: I7baa623fd71a7d03acc61dd1f18287bb654539cd
Partial-Bug: #1266962

commit_message:
Add tools/test-setup.sh script to setup test environment

Add simple script to setup the test environment as needed by unit-tests.

This script can be used by users to setup their test environment.

It will be run by OpenStack CI systems as specific setup
before running unit tests.

Change-Id: I86d8be3b87f5c1006c8f756152799965bc7b05c9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-searchlightclient refs/changes/58/399158/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash -xe # This script will be run by OpenStack CI before unit tests are run, # it sets up the test system as needed. # Developer should setup their test systems in a similar way. # This setup needs to be run by a user that can run sudo. sudo apt-get update sudo apt-get install -y default-jre wget https://download.elastic.co/elasticsearch/release/org/elasticsearch/distribution/deb/elasticsearch/2.3.2/elasticsearch-2.3.2.deb sudo dpkg -i elasticsearch-2.3.2.deb # Make 'elasticsearch' binary callable from within functional tests sudo ln -s /usr/share/elasticsearch/bin/elasticsearch /usr/local/bin/elasticsearch

commit_message:
Replace uuid4() with generate_uuid() from oslo_utils

UUID can be generated using uuid4() as well as
uuidutils.generate_utils(). Since we are using the latter in the
Mistral code, we shall maintain the same on the client as well.

Change-Id: I65c27bb6253cecc80bd538ba6d59022141d22b6c
Closes-Bug: #1082248
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-mistralclient refs/changes/48/399448/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_utils import uuidutilsAUTH_TOKEN = uuidutils.generate_uuid() PROJECT_ID = uuidutils.generate_uuid() USER_ID = uuidutils.generate_uuid()PROFILER_TRACE_ID = uuidutils.generate_uuid() target_auth_url = uuidutils.generate_uuid() target_auth_token = uuidutils.generate_uuid()
deleted_lines: import uuidAUTH_TOKEN = str(uuid.uuid4()) PROJECT_ID = str(uuid.uuid4()) USER_ID = str(uuid.uuid4())PROFILER_TRACE_ID = str(uuid.uuid4()) target_auth_url = str(uuid.uuid4()) target_auth_token = str(uuid.uuid4())

added_lines: def test_publish_bad_jinja(self): wf_text = """--- version: '2.0' wf: type: direct input: - my_dict: - id: 1 value: 11 tasks: task1: action: std.noop publish: problem_var: '{{ (_.my_dict|some_invalid_filter).id }}' """ wf_service.create_workflows(wf_text) wf_ex = self.engine.start_workflow('wf', {}) self.await_workflow_error(wf_ex.id) with db_api.transaction(): wf_ex = db_api.get_workflow_execution(wf_ex.id) task_ex = wf_ex.task_executions[0] action_ex = task_ex.action_executions[0] self.assertEqual(states.SUCCESS, action_ex.state) self.assertEqual(states.ERROR, task_ex.state) self.assertIsNotNone(task_ex.state_info) self.assertEqual(states.ERROR, wf_ex.state)

commit_message:
Default $STABLE_RELEASE in bootstrap-overcloud-full.sh

This script is meant to be able to be used standalone as well as from
tripleo-ci. The $STABLE_RELEASE variable needs to be defaulted to an
empty string otherwise the script will fail since it is set -u.

Change-Id: I6aa8bd3b01b1147de9b45f40ded8318fb46dcaf8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci refs/changes/59/385159/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: export STABLE_RELEASE=${STABLE_RELEASE:-""}

subject: (fix gate) Set up networking for Neutron
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-18 20:36:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/bb18128368b2b2196dc742702fdf1ded37959ff8', 'message': "(fix gate) Set up networking for Neutron

Now that devstack uses Neutron by default (and so does the gate)
we need to open the private network to access it through the
alt_demo tenant for the int-tests to work.
(see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/355492 )

The tcp_ports configuration was also moved to facilitate both
network styles.

The 'PUBLIC_INTERFACE=eth0' line was also moved to be in just
nova networking as it is not necessary for Neutron (and caused
the network to become unstable).  This should allow it to
continue working for backwards compatibility if required.

A number of changes to code and/or tests were also required.
Since these are specifically tied to the switch to neutron
(as they are equally valid for nova-net) they have been
made separately and referenced below in the 'Depends-On' list.
This should also facilitate easier reviews and make it
possible to backport any of the fixes if required.

Change-Id: I3359b679c870ea48cb1a8f55d316204079e246fe
Depends-On: I8f3d0d2a77999fc15ba10044930b37c030ad63dd

"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-11-18 21:43:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/5b659cf05a9437de244d1a07ccee463418ab2d22', 'message': "(fix gate) Set up networking for Neutron

Now that devstack uses Neutron by default (and so does the gate)
we need to open the private network to access it through the
alt_demo tenant for the int-tests to work.
(see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/355492 )

The tcp_ports configuration was also moved to facilitate both
network styles.

The 'PUBLIC_INTERFACE=eth0' line was also moved to be in just
nova networking as it is not necessary for Neutron (and caused
the network to become unstable).  This should allow it to
continue working for backwards compatibility if required.

A number of changes to code and/or tests were also required.
Since these are specifically tied to the switch to neutron
(as they are equally valid for nova-net) they have been
made separately and referenced below in the 'Depends-On' list.
This should also facilitate easier reviews and make it
possible to backport any of the fixes if required.

Change-Id: I3359b679c870ea48cb1a8f55d316204079e246fe
Depends-On: I8f3d0d2a77999fc15ba10044930b37c030ad63dd

Closes-Bug: #1613889

commit_message:
(fix gate) Set up networking for Neutron

Now that devstack uses Neutron by default (and so does the gate)
we need to open the private network to access it through the
alt_demo tenant for the int-tests to work.
(see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/355492 )

The tcp_ports configuration was also moved to facilitate both
network styles.

The 'PUBLIC_INTERFACE=eth0' line was also moved to be in just
nova networking as it is not necessary for Neutron (and caused
the network to become unstable).  This should allow it to
continue working for backwards compatibility if required.

A number of changes to code and/or tests were also required.
Since these are specifically tied to the switch to neutron
(as they are equally valid for nova-net) they have been
made separately and referenced below in the 'Depends-On' list.
This should also facilitate easier reviews and make it
possible to backport any of the fixes if required.

Change-Id: I3359b679c870ea48cb1a8f55d316204079e246fe
Depends-On: I8f3d0d2a77999fc15ba10044930b37c030ad63dd
Depends-On: I136141b3db78b7a0a1804bb5e3d4ca5cf4bc3bb3
Depends-On: I82d6fafc32068c646da0416d91d5f00352091ee2
Depends-On: I47cbe9e899cb0767c377d184f123e38eda5b6a05
Depends-On: I2ede074eb9bdf26420750f19f3aa4b8d057c5d7d
Depends-On: I6aff776680c9c0632d8965c3ed70ed26db0a63f2
Depends-On: I54edc4acac09ca2278f525c08ad0d87576f0549e
Depends-On: Iab530fe503336c83e9b948c2c008d371a8030a1e

subject: Use assert_called_*/assert_not_called to verify mock calls
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-14 10:11:11.000000000', 'files': ['magnumclient/tests/v1/test_certificates_shell.py', 'magnumclient/tests/v1/test_mservices_shell.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-magnumclient/commit/bafc850379b1e290914ea5e7050cb97d66130b2d', 'message': 'Use assert_called_*/assert_not_called to verify mock calls

Currently assertTrue and assertFalse are used to check
wheter a mock method is called. It is not checked whether
mock method is called with correct set of arguments.
With this patch following modules uses assert_called_* and
assert_not_called instead of assertTrue and assertFalse.

- magnumclient/tests/v1/test_certificates_shell.py
- magnumclient/tests/v1/test_mservices_shell.py

Also, renamed "file_mock" to "mock_file" for consistent
mock naming in the modules.

Change-Id: I706b362509f6a59be13df8d9c132e4f4b68e0060
Partially-Implements: blueprint magnumclient-ut-coverage
'}]
commit_message:
Use assert_called_*/assert_not_called to verify mock calls

Currently assertTrue and assertFalse are used to check
wheter a mock method is called. It is not checked whether
mock method is called with correct set of arguments.
With this patch following modules uses assert_called_* and
assert_not_called instead of assertTrue and assertFalse.

- magnumclient/tests/v1/test_certificates_shell.py
- magnumclient/tests/v1/test_mservices_shell.py

Also, renamed "file_mock" to "mock_file" for consistent
mock naming in the modules.

Change-Id: I706b362509f6a59be13df8d9c132e4f4b68e0060
Partially-Implements: blueprint magnumclient-ut-coverage

commit_message:
Increase unit test coverage for muranodashboard Packages Tables
and Packages API.

In addition, renamed and moved the following test files for
better organization in the unit test directory:
- test_tables -> environments/test_tables
- test_packages -> packages/test_api

Lastly, updated packages/test_views to fix single failing
test in py27-mitaka-ubuntu-xenial.

Implements bp: murano-unit-test-coverage

Change-Id: I57813b0c68b4538616f6ecf03d2b92d535556645

muranoclient.common import exceptions as exc from muranodashboard.packages import tables class TestImportPackage(testtools.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestImportPackage, self).setUp() self.import_package = tables.ImportPackage() self.assertEqual('upload_package', self.import_package.name) self.assertEqual('Import Package', self.import_package.verbose_name) self.assertEqual('horizon:app-catalog:packages:upload', self.import_package.url) self.assertEqual(('ajax-modal',), self.import_package.classes) self.assertEqual('plus', self.import_package.icon) self.assertEqual((('murano', 'upload_package'),), self.import_package.policy_rules) @mock.patch.object(tables, 'api') def test_allowed(self, mock_api): mock_api.muranoclient().packages.categories.return_value = ['foo_cat'] self.assertTrue(self.import_package.allowed(None, None)) mock_api.muranoclient().packages.categories.return_value = None self.assertFalse(self.import_package.allowed(None, None)) class TestDownloadPackage(testtools.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestDownloadPackage, self).setUp() self.download_package = tables.DownloadPackage() self.assertEqual('download_package', self.download_package.name) self.assertEqual('Download Package', self.download_package.verbose_name) self.assertEqual((('murano', 'download_package'),), self.download_package.policy_rules) self.assertEqual('horizon:app-catalog:packages:download', self.download_package.url) def test_allowed(self): self.assertTrue(self.download_package.allowed(None, None)) @mock.patch.object(tables, 'reverse') def test_get_link_url(self, mock_reverse): mock_reverse.return_value = 'foo_reverse_url' mock_app = mock.Mock(id='foo_app_id') mock_app.configure_mock(name='FOO APP') result = self.download_package.get_link_url(mock_app) self.assertEqual('foo_reverse_url', result) mock_reverse.assert_called_once_with( 'horizon:app-catalog:packages:download', args=('foo-app', 'foo_app_id')) class TestToggleEnabled(testtools.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestToggleEnabled, self).setUp() self.mock_request = mock.Mock() self.toggle_enabled = tables.ToggleEnabled() self.toggle_enabled.request = self.mock_request self.assertEqual('toggle_enabled', self.toggle_enabled.name) self.assertEqual('Toggle Enabled', self.toggle_enabled.verbose_name) self.assertEqual('toggle-on', self.toggle_enabled.icon) self.assertEqual((('murano', 'modify_package'),), self.toggle_enabled.policy_rules) def test_action_present(self): self.assertEqual('Toggle Active', tables.ToggleEnabled.action_present(1)) self.assertEqual('Toggle Active', tables.ToggleEnabled.action_present(2)) def test_action_past(self): self.assertEqual('Toggled Active', tables.ToggleEnabled.action_past(1)) self.assertEqual('Toggled Active', tables.ToggleEnabled.action_past(2)) @mock.patch.object(tables, 'LOG') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'api') def test_action(self, mock_api, mock_log): self.toggle_enabled.action(self.mock_request, 'foo_package_id') mock_api.muranoclient().packages.toggle_active.assert_called_once_with( 'foo_package_id') mock_log.debug.assert_called_once_with('Toggle Active for package ' 'foo_package_id.') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'reverse') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'messages') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'exceptions') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'LOG') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'api') def test_action_except_http_forbidden(self, mock_api, mock_log, mock_exc, mock_messages, mock_reverse): mock_api.muranoclient().packages.toggle_active.side_effect = \ exc.HTTPForbidden mock_reverse.return_value = 'foo_reverse_url' expected_msg = _('You are not allowed to perform this operation') self.toggle_enabled.action(self.mock_request, 'foo_package_id') mock_api.muranoclient().packages.toggle_active.assert_called_once_with( 'foo_package_id') mock_log.exception.assert_called_once_with(expected_msg) mock_messages.error.assert_called_once_with(self.mock_request, expected_msg) mock_exc.handle.assert_called_once_with(self.mock_request, expected_msg, redirect='foo_reverse_url') mock_reverse.assert_called_once_with( 'horizon:app-catalog:packages:index') class TestTogglePublicEnabled(testtools.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestTogglePublicEnabled, self).setUp() self.mock_request = mock.Mock() self.toggle_public_enabled = tables.TogglePublicEnabled() self.toggle_public_enabled.request = self.mock_request self.assertEqual('toggle_public_enabled', self.toggle_public_enabled.name) self.assertEqual('share-alt', self.toggle_public_enabled.icon) self.assertEqual((('murano', 'publicize_package'),), self.toggle_public_enabled.policy_rules) def test_action_present(self): self.assertEqual('Toggle Public', tables.TogglePublicEnabled.action_present(1)) self.assertEqual('Toggle Public', tables.TogglePublicEnabled.action_present(2)) def test_action_past(self): self.assertEqual('Toggled Public', tables.TogglePublicEnabled.action_past(1)) self.assertEqual('Toggled Public', tables.TogglePublicEnabled.action_past(2)) @mock.patch.object(tables, 'LOG') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'api') def test_action(self, mock_api, mock_log): self.toggle_public_enabled.action(self.mock_request, 'foo_package_id') mock_api.muranoclient().packages.toggle_public.assert_called_once_with( 'foo_package_id') mock_log.debug.assert_called_once_with( 'Toggle Public for package foo_package_id.') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'reverse') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'messages') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'exceptions') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'LOG') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'api') def test_action_except_http_forbidden(self, mock_api, mock_log, mock_exc, mock_messages, mock_reverse): mock_api.muranoclient().packages.toggle_public.side_effect = \ exc.HTTPForbidden mock_reverse.return_value = 'foo_reverse_url' expected_msg = _('You are not allowed to perform this operation') self.toggle_public_enabled.action(self.mock_request, 'foo_package_id') mock_api.muranoclient().packages.toggle_public.assert_called_once_with( 'foo_package_id') mock_log.exception.assert_called_once_with(expected_msg) mock_messages.error.assert_called_once_with(self.mock_request, expected_msg) mock_exc.handle.assert_called_once_with(self.mock_request, expected_msg, redirect='foo_reverse_url') mock_reverse.assert_called_once_with( 'horizon:app-catalog:packages:index') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'reverse') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'messages') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'exceptions') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'LOG') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'api') def test_action_except_http_conflict(self, mock_api, mock_log, mock_exc, mock_messages, mock_reverse): mock_api.muranoclient().packages.toggle_public.side_effect = \ exc.HTTPConflict mock_reverse.return_value = 'foo_reverse_url' expected_msg = _('Package or Class with the same name is already made ' 'public') self.toggle_public_enabled.action(self.mock_request, 'foo_package_id') mock_api.muranoclient().packages.toggle_public.assert_called_once_with( 'foo_package_id') mock_log.exception.assert_called_once_with(expected_msg) mock_messages.error.assert_called_once_with(self.mock_request, expected_msg) mock_exc.handle.assert_called_once_with(self.mock_request, expected_msg, redirect='foo_reverse_url') mock_reverse.assert_called_once_with( 'horizon:app-catalog:packages:index') class TestDeletePackage(testtools.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestDeletePackage, self).setUp() self.mock_request = mock.Mock() self.delete_package = tables.DeletePackage() self.delete_package.request = self.mock_request self.assertEqual('delete_package', self.delete_package.name) self.assertEqual((('murano', 'delete_package'),), self.delete_package.policy_rules) def test_action_present(self): self.assertEqual('Delete Package', tables.DeletePackage.action_present(1)) self.assertEqual('Delete Packages', tables.DeletePackage.action_present(2)) def test_action_past(self): self.assertEqual('Deleted Package', tables.DeletePackage.action_past(1)) self.assertEqual('Deleted Packages', tables.DeletePackage.action_past(2)) @mock.patch.object(tables, 'LOG') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'api') def test_delete(self, mock_api, mock_log): self.delete_package.delete(self.mock_request, 'foo_package_id') mock_api.muranoclient().packages.delete.assert_called_once_with( 'foo_package_id') mock_log.exception.assert_not_called() @mock.patch.object(tables, 'reverse') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'exceptions') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'LOG') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'api') def test_delete_except_http_not_found(self, mock_api, mock_log, mock_exc, mock_reverse): mock_api.muranoclient().packages.delete.side_effect = exc.HTTPNotFound mock_reverse.return_value = 'foo_reverse_url' expected_msg = _('Package with id foo_package_id is not found') self.delete_package.delete(self.mock_request, 'foo_package_id') mock_api.muranoclient().packages.delete.assert_called_once_with( 'foo_package_id') mock_log.exception.assert_called_once_with(expected_msg) mock_exc.handle.assert_called_once_with(self.mock_request, expected_msg, redirect='foo_reverse_url') mock_reverse.assert_called_once_with( 'horizon:app-catalog:packages:index') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'reverse') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'exceptions') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'LOG') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'api') def test_delete_except_http_forbidden(self, mock_api, mock_log, mock_exc, mock_reverse): mock_api.muranoclient().packages.delete.side_effect = exc.HTTPForbidden mock_reverse.return_value = 'foo_reverse_url' expected_msg = _('You are not allowed to delete this package') self.delete_package.delete(self.mock_request, 'foo_package_id') mock_api.muranoclient().packages.delete.assert_called_once_with( 'foo_package_id') mock_log.exception.assert_called_once_with(expected_msg) mock_exc.handle.assert_called_once_with(self.mock_request, expected_msg, redirect='foo_reverse_url') mock_reverse.assert_called_once_with( 'horizon:app-catalog:packages:index') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'reverse') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'exceptions') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'LOG') @mock.patch.object(tables, 'api') def test_delete_except_exception(self, mock_api, mock_log, mock_exc, mock_reverse): mock_api.muranoclient().packages.delete.side_effect = Exception mock_reverse.return_value = 'foo_reverse_url' expected_log_msg = _('Unable to delete package in murano-api server') self.delete_package.delete(self.mock_request, 'foo_package_id') mock_api.muranoclient().packages.delete.assert_called_once_with( 'foo_package_id') mock_log.exception.assert_called_once_with(expected_log_msg) mock_exc.handle.assert_called_once_with(self.mock_request, _('Unable to remove package.'), redirect='foo_reverse_url') mock_reverse.assert_called_once_with( 'horizon:app-catalog:packages:index') class TestModifyPackage(testtools.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestModifyPackage, self).setUp() self.modify_package = tables.ModifyPackage() self.assertEqual('modify_package', self.modify_package.name) self.assertEqual(_('Modify Package'), self.modify_package.verbose_name) self.assertEqual('horizon:app-catalog:packages:modify', self.modify_package.url) self.assertEqual(('ajax-modal',), self.modify_package.classes) self.assertEqual('edit', self.modify_package.icon) self.assertEqual((('murano', 'modify_package'),), self.modify_package.policy_rules) def test_allowed(self): self.assertTrue(self.modify_package.allowed(None, None))

commit_message:
Fix: some typos in unit test

'--fixed-network private-subnet ' -> '--fixed-subnet private-subnet '
'--server-type vm' -> '--server-type vm '
'--coe swarm' -> '--coe swarm '

Change-Id: I82b9eaf649e14f97e08b2324ff370d528a1d033f

subject: Replace 'assertEqual(None, ...)' with 'assertIsNone(...)'
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-21 06:10:24.000000000', 'files': ['muranodashboard/tests/unit/packages/test_views.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/murano-dashboard/commit/6ebe2b661973ecfcb19f7634218297591389443a', 'message': "Replace 'assertEqual(None, ...)' with 'assertIsNone(...)'

[H203] Use assertIs(Not)None to check for None (off by default) Unit
test assertions tend to give better messages for more specific
assertions. As a result, assertIsNone(...) is preferred over
assertEqual(None, ...) and assertIs(None, ...), and assertIsNotNone(...)
is preferred over assertNotEqual(None, ...) and assertIsNot(None,
...). Off by default.

Trivial fix.

Change-Id: I3f103981e397af7a556468fbf485f6e062c328d1
"}]
commit_message:
Replace 'assertEqual(None, ...)' with 'assertIsNone(...)'

[H203] Use assertIs(Not)None to check for None (off by default) Unit
test assertions tend to give better messages for more specific
assertions. As a result, assertIsNone(...) is preferred over
assertEqual(None, ...) and assertIs(None, ...), and assertIsNotNone(...)
is preferred over assertNotEqual(None, ...) and assertIsNot(None,
...). Off by default.

Trivial fix.

Change-Id: I3f103981e397af7a556468fbf485f6e062c328d1

added_lines: self.assertIsNone(mock_package.tenant_name)
deleted_lines: self.assertEqual(None, mock_package.tenant_name)

subject: Don't use rc.local to start fix-configs-on-startup
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-18 12:13:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-agent/commit/402c2784a92a3106fb65a9cbe70962d10c35c269', 'message': "Don't use rc.local to start fix-configs-on-startup

It looks like mcollective is restarted two times duting boot
process. First, it simply restarted by nailgun-agent to change
node's ID. And then it gets restarted by fix-configs-on-startup
after it fixes mcollective's configuration file.

It turns out that such sequence of restarts may cause node's
provisioning problems when node's boot process is delayed. The
simpe workaround is to run fix-configs-on-startup by nailgun-agent
and exclude fix-configs-on-startup from rc.local.

Change-Id: I28b8d632faa753b693eb2277c5989092f29afa21
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-11-21 13:45:54.000000000', 'files': ['contrib/fuel_bootstrap/files/trusty/etc/rc.local'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-agent/commit/fee9393540cf7876301f7456b5ccfe8cebd96590', 'message': "Don't use rc.local to start fix-configs-on-startup

It looks like mcollective is restarted two times duting boot

node's ID. And then it gets restarted by fix-configs-on-startup
after it fixes mcollective's configuration file.

It turns out that such sequence of restarts may cause node's
provisioning problems when node's boot process is delayed. The
simpe workaround is to run fix-configs-on-startup by nailgun-agent

Change-Id: I28b8d632faa753b693eb2277c5989092f29afa21
"}]
commit_message:
Don't use rc.local to start fix-configs-on-startup

It looks like mcollective is restarted two times duting boot
process. First, it simply restarted by nailgun-agent to change
node's ID. And then it gets restarted by fix-configs-on-startup
after it fixes mcollective's configuration file.

It turns out that such sequence of restarts may cause node's
provisioning problems when node's boot process is delayed. The
simpe workaround is to run fix-configs-on-startup by nailgun-agent
and exclude fix-configs-on-startup from rc.local.

Change-Id: I28b8d632faa753b693eb2277c5989092f29afa21
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-agent refs/changes/65/399565/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: # Perform fuel bootstrap configuration fix-configs-on-startup || true

commit_message:
Fix mongo logs verbosity

W/o this patch a mongo logs are too huge to be processed by
logrotate without issues.

The solution is to reduce the non debug verbosity level for logs
and do not log all transactions as well (use the quiet option):
* Sync the quiet parameter from puppetlabs-mongodb v0.10.0
* Lower the logs verbosity for a non debug case
* Use the quiet parameter for a non debug case

Closes-bug: #1427197
Related-bug: #1393400

Change-Id: I3a3ba70029167928565baa46a77a5c0c0dbacbe8
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
Signed-off-by: Sergii Golovatiuk <sgolovatiuk@mirantis.com>
(cherry picked from commit 3f99d39be882cd6a05d4f07f95c3cc8ffb3f4f00)

commit_message:
Use endpoint as endpoint_override

Number of projects like rally pass endpoint rather than
endpoint_override when using session with heatclient.

Use endpoint as endpoint_override when not specified.

Make it backward compatible.

Change-Id: Iff977424a15ac2ce3ffdf8d7c98d5e72d25c1e91
Closes-Bug: #1643507
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/95/400195/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if 'endpoint_override' not in kwargs and endpoint: kwargs['endpoint_override'] = endpoint

commit_message:
Modify development doc url in CONTRIBUTING.rst

The old url shows the steps of submitting the changes for review, but
not the preparations for contributing, so i think it is better to delete
the '#development-workflow' section to give the new contributor a clear
document url.

Trivial fix.

Change-Id: I765411b930d06ac35ce79661228e0a0e413dc191

commit_message:
Allow bifrost to work with selinux enabled

Currently when selinux is enabled, nginx fails with permission
denied on /httpboot, and could not bind to address errors.
To fix port issues: add the right rule to selinux
To fix permission issues: add the right policies and custom
modules to selinux

Change-Id: Ieb5afe758981940a04c5076d2cebd6746db57da1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/bifrost refs/changes/45/393745/34 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: "Explicitly allow nginx port (TCP) on selinux" seport: ports: 8080 proto: tcp setype: http_port_t state: present

commit_message:
Use messagingv2 by default

Messaging driver should only be used in cases where there are existing
consumers deployed which do not support the 2.0 message format [1]. We
need to change to use messagingv2 instead of messaging driver in
devstack and documentation.

[1]:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.messaging/notifier.html?highlight=messagingv2#messaging

Change-Id: Iaed12f4b62bc7efe0ab37489b86acdfdd9449267
Closes-bug: #1643433

commit_message:
Revert "[PY3] byte/string conversions and enable PY3 test"

This reverts commit 0f152eb66153e16d4d8aba0f8afebaab046aea35.

the change to nova/api/openstack/wsgi.py breaks if nova is deployed over
mod_wsgi. In python 2.X it expects headers to be byte strings while this
converted them to unicode. However, in python 3.X it does expect
unicode.

This commit is being reverted since it breaks TripleO (since it deploys
nova over httpd.

Change-Id: Ie6f8afdb7fd22ff85bc17f3163d3e1bcb544a96c
Closes-Bug: #1643511

commit_message:
Remove brackets from doc config example

The password_expires_ignore_user_ids example in the docs includes [],
which should not be there. This patch removes them.

Change-Id: I954c339edcf2322e21548bbc3a5351f1663f6f1f

commit_message:
add ipa-api-url in pxe default config

We need to add ipa-api-url in $TFTPROOT/pxelinux.cfg/default, or
it will use http://127.0.0.1:6385/ as the default ironic api url
on ramdisk while inspecting the node, add report ConnectionError.

Change-Id: I13cdf107a06c2aff11d468f51278e3bec343d78b

commit_message:
Do not just return when calling legacy image build

The return statement was not allowing the client to return a useful
error code when the legacy build failed. This change allows it to
return something meaningful by letting the ImageBuildError bubble up.

Change-Id: I5e614fd08ca72769dd4986a8abe4ba64cca55da0
Closes-Bug: #1632753
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/64/398364/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch('os.path.isfile', autospec=True) @mock.patch('platform.linux_distribution') @mock.patch.object(overcloud_image.BuildOvercloudImage, '_build_image_fedora_user', autospec=True) def test_overcloud_image_build_all_with_error(self, mock_fedora_user, mock_linux_distribution, mock_os_path_isfile): arglist = ['--all'] verifylist = [('all', True)] parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, verifylist) mock_linux_distribution.return_value = ['CentOS Fake Release'] mock_os_path_isfile.side_effect = [False, True, False, False, True] self.assertRaises(overcloud_image.ImageBuildError, self.cmd.take_action, parsed_args)

commit_message:
Enable enforce_password_check

By setting ENFORCE_PASSWORD_CHECK to `True`, it displays an 'Admin
Password' field on the Change Password form to verify that it is indeed
the admin logged-in who wants to change the password.

Change-Id: Ib11bef93b6b0c74063052875fa361290bf1e92fd
Depends-On: If7af97df7a011569a7e14fbab4f880688d7b82c3
Closes-Bug: #1640806

commit_message:
Change the tunnel_key in df_db

Since change in [1], the tunnel key table has been renamed to unique key.
To make df_db work with it, the table name needs to update too.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/387840

Change-Id: Ibfaa4c2661b893e30b3b2369e1c55659d9c6547d
Related-Bug: #1633082
